repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Because we do not build neovim for IBM s390x architecture ourselves (Linux distributions do this for us) and we want to enable luajit support on our architecture, this patch ensures that luajit2 instead of luajit is used on big endian architectures.

comment_regular_data.body:
Thank you, but no. We only officially support LuaJIT and (where that is not available) PUC Lua.

You are very welcome to make these changes downstream, like every other distribution.
@julianruess there were several attempts on getting s390 mainlined to LuaJIT, you can check their PRs and maybe revive the effort.

I believe what's missing there is someone sponsoring Mike Pall for adding (and keeping!) support for a new architecture.

To the best of my knowledge (but I've not verified this for a while), OpenResty/LuaJIT2 is a drop-in replacement for LuaJIT, and I personally would recommend that (if you don't have the cash lying around to get the expert to Do It Right).

However, we will not officially support both runtimes (and prefer the one maintained by said expert) -- especially not since the motivation here is IBM s390x, which we also don't and can't officially support. (Rule of thumb: if we can't test it, we can't support it. It's hard enough keeping everything working on the platforms we currently support, with all their local idiosyncrasies.)

Such adaptations are the distribution's job, so if building yourself is not an option, you should bring this up with them (adding the caveat that Neovim does not support building against LuaJIT2, and any issues that arise from that are their problem).

I still stand by what [I said before](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23603#issuecomment-1546619027):

> I don't think we can officially take on a third lua alternative (lua, luajit and luajit2) from a maintenance standpoint. Lua is supposed to be the fallback in cases where luajit isn't available.

Even supporting just lua and luajit can be time consuming with a bunch of nasty edge cases, and adding luajit2 on top of this doesn't sound fun.

That said I think this can be solved without our involvment. I don't see a reason why distributions can't opt to choose luajit2 instead of lua on big endian systems. We have (for better or worse) zero control how distributions choose to build neovim. If you suggest this to the neovim package maintainer for a distro and they agree with you then that should solve your problem IMO.
Also, I find it a bit disingenuous to make this PR without linking to your previous issue, which ended with a clear resolution against the very change your propose here.
The last issue was a suggestion to replace luajit with luajit2 on all architectures. This one only affects big endian architectures. There was no clear resolution against this.

I'm sorry, but what part of "we won't support s390x" and "we won't add support for a third Lua runtime" was unclear? In any case, you should have linked the issue and explained why this PR is different.

(Don't get me wrong, we'd _love_ if Neovim had first-class support on s390x. But _we_ can't make this happen for lack of manpower and infrastructure. If _you_ volunteer to maintain that support on a long enough time horizon, we'd be happy to reconsider.)

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23603

@dundargoc:
"This seems to work fine when I did a quick test. Of course, we can't make any guarantees that this'll continue to work in the future, and any issues with this setup will be instaclosed with "we don't support that, so don't do that". But if this is a risk you're fine with then that is also a possibility."

What I don't understand is that even today you're not able to test neovim (without luajit) on s390x, right? So what prevents you from adding a few lines that you also cannot test?

> What I don't understand is that even today you're not able to test neovim (without luajit) on s390x, right? So what prevents you from adding a few lines that you also cannot test?

Because we haven't added anything _specific_ that we can't test. If it works, fine, enjoy the freebie, but no guarantees; no reason to _prohibit_ it. But we won't make _any_ changes to our build scripts (which are a house of cards already) that we can't test.

> What I don't understand is that even today you're not able to test neovim (without luajit) on s390x, right? So what prevents you from adding a few lines that you also cannot test?

I don't feel comfortable adding code we don't intend to maintain. If this breaks in the future we'll still need to either fix it or remove it. We're responsible that all code works at the end of the day.

I also feel you haven't done a good case as to why PUC lua isn't sufficient for your use case. I get the impression PUC lua (in general) gets a bad rep due to have insanely fast luajit is, but it is by no means slow.

Most importantly: I want to emphasize that distributions modify our build scripts however they want and that we have no control on what they do. Even if we merge this there is nothing stopping distros to just replace luajit2 with lua on big endian systems if they want to.

For curiosity: which distributions are you thinking about?

We want to migrate some setups from vim to neovim because it is awesome what is possible with it and it has a better community.

I tried to build neovim by hand on s390x and it failed because it cannot install the luajit dependency. Should that be the case when following the default neovim build instructions when PUC lua is the default? Because of this I thought we need luajit. Nevertheless I played around with some modern package managers like lazy.nvim or packer.nvim and it seems that they require luajit. Are there also plugins right now (or in the future) that require luajit? This just seemed to me that we're not really future proof by just using PUC lua.

Yes, we can also ask the Linux distributions (Suse, Red Hat, Ubuntu, Fedora) to build neovim with luajit2 for us but this is a lot of effort and hard to handle.

Yes, some plugins require LuaJIT (for FFI); in this case you need to manually edit the `deps.txt` file like we showed you; then a simple `make` should go through.

Feel free to reach out on https://matrix.to/#/#neovim:matrix.org if you need assistance.

> This just seemed to me that we're not really future proof by just using PUC lua.

It's the complete opposite, actually: by setting the baseline to vanilla Lua 5.1, we are _more_ future-proof because we do not tie ourselves to a single (or double, with the LuaJIT2 fork) specific runtime that can go away or make unacceptable changes.

> Yes, we can also ask the Linux distributions (Suse, Red Hat, Ubuntu, Fedora) to build neovim with luajit2 for us but this is a lot of effort and hard to handle.

Yes, but that is effort with a much greater payoff, not just for you (and required even if we make the requested change, since distributions in general do not use our build scripts for dependencies).

@julianruess fyi: I have multiple popular plugins that require LuaJIT.
`lazy`, `noice`, `flash` and `edgy`

It is easier for us to have changes upstream and tell the distributions "just build as upstream". But you're right, this is not the right place here to make this change. I'm currently in discussions with the distributions and I'll let you know if there will be decisions regarding replacing luajit with luajit2 for all packages and not only on s390x. Sorry for the inconvenience :-)

> It is easier for us to have changes upstream and tell the distributions "just build as upstream". 

Oh, you sweet summer child... 

(Again, just to be clear: **no** distro "just builds as upstream". The fact alone that we statically link our dependencies means they torch our build scripts with fire.)

> decisions regarding replacing luajit with luajit2 for all packages

I don't think that will be acceptable, as LuaJIT is the source of truth here and gets faster security updates (and is the one tested by us). I see LuaJIT2 only as a reasonable (for now) drop-in replacement for those very few architectures which they support but LuaJIT doesn't.

> I tried to build neovim by hand on s390x and it failed because it cannot install the luajit dependency. Should that be the case when following the default neovim build instructions when PUC lua is the default?

Luajit is the default, not PUC lua. PUC lua is meant as a fallback/replacement when luajit can't be used. If you mean that PUC lua should be chosen by default on s390x then I guess that's a fair point.

> Nevertheless I played around with some modern package managers like lazy.nvim or packer.nvim and it seems that they require luajit.

I'm fairly sure packer.nvim does not require luajit. What makes you think it does?

> Are there also plugins right now (or in the future) that require luajit?

It looks like anything by folke will require luajit. Other than that a luajit requirement is rare. We don't govern how plugins are developed so I can't tell you how future plugins will be like.

> This just seemed to me that we're not really future proof by just using PUC lua.

I don't understand what you mean. A single plugin author decided to have luajit as a requirement for their plugins. How can we possibly draw meaningful conclusions from this?

> Yes, we can also ask the Linux distributions (Suse, Red Hat, Ubuntu, Fedora) to build neovim with luajit2 for us but this is a lot of effort and hard to handle.

I asked so *I* could contact the relevant distribution. If you and your team really use 5 different linux distros then I guess that's out of the question regardless.

I think this issue is at the end of the road and that there's not much we can do. You should already be able to download neovim on s390x with your distros package manager, although with PUC lua. Most plugins will work just fine with that. If that's not sufficient then we've already provided a way for you to manually install neovim with luajit2. Why are these workarounds not sufficient?
If you're serious about this and do want to see it through (and you have the resources for it) then the best way is to fund Mike Pall to fix luajit for the s390x system.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim_luajit2

labels.description: building and installing Neovim using the provided scripts
labels.name: build

title: Use luajit2 instead of luajit on big endian machines
